required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: CTA101 in the Treatment of Relapsed or Refractory Diffuse Large B-cell Lymphoma
clinical_study.official_title: A Phase I Clinical Trial of CTA101 UCART Cells Injection in the Treatment of Relapsed or Refractory Diffuse Large B-cell Lymphoma

lead_sponsor.agency: The First Affiliated Hospital with Nanjing Medical University

clinical_study.source: The First Affiliated Hospital with Nanjing Medical University

brief_summary.textblock: This is a single-center, non-randomized and dose-escalation study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of CTA101 in relapsed or refractory diffuse large B-cell lymphoma patients.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline up to 35 days after T cell infusion
primary_outcome.description: Adverse events assessed according to NCI-CTCAE v4.03 criteria

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 4 weeks, 12 weeks, 6 months, 12 months, 18 months and 24 months
secondary_outcome.description: Assessment of overall response rate for weeks 4, 12, months 6, 12, 18 and 24 in accordance with Lugano 2014 (overall response rate，OR)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 12 weeks, 6 months, 12 months, 18 months and 24 months
secondary_outcome.description: Assessment of overall response rate for weeks 12, months 6, 12, 18 and 24 in accordance with Lugano 2014（disease control rate，DCR)

intervention.description: Universal CD19-directed CAR-T cells by a single infusion intravenously will be given in escalating doses. Subjects will been distributed into low dose (0.2×10^6), medium dose (2×10^6), and high dose (3×10^6).

facility.name: the First Affiliated Hospital of Nanjing Medical University
